qas.question: How do prokaryotes store their genomes?

answers.text: on a single large, circular chromosome

qas.question: What type of chromosome do some eukaryotic organelles contain?

answers.text: a remnant circular chromosome with a small number of genes

qas.question: Small circles of DNA that encode only a few genes and are transferable between individuals are called what?
What allows genes for antibiotic resistance to be passed between individual cells?

context: Prokaryotes (<a0_0>bacteria and archaea<a0_0/>) typically store their genomes <a1_0>on a single large, circular chromosome<a1_0/>. Similarly, some eukaryotic organelles contain <a2_0>a remnant circular chromosome with a small number of genes<a2_0/>.:14.4 Prokaryotes sometimes supplement their chromosome with additional small circles of DNA called <a3_0>plasmids<a3_0/>, which usually encode only a few genes and are transferable between individuals. For example, the genes for antibiotic resistance are usually encoded on bacterial plasmids and can be passed between individual cells, even those of different species, via <a4_0>horizontal gene transfer<a4_0/>.
